basics.name: Nicu Calcea
basics.label: Investigative Data Journalist
basics.summary: Nicu Calcea is a journalist with 15 years of experience in media, specialising in investigative data reporting. Currently based in London.

work.name: Global Witness
work.summary: With colleagues in the Fossil Fuels Campaign, I work on long-term investigations on the leading issues related to climate change. I supported some of Global Witness’s biggest outputs of 2024, including the annual Land and Environmental Defenders report and the AI-assisted classification of fossil fuel lobbyists at COP29.
highlights: Investigated fossil fuel donors' $19 million contribution to Trump's inaugural fund
Pioneered AI-assisted approach to identify fossil fuel lobbyists at COP29

work.name: City, University of London
work.summary: I teach a data journalism basics class to postgraduate students. The course is a hands-on introduction to data collection, analysis, visualisation and communication.
highlights: Developed comprehensive training resources for data journalism students
Provides professional data journalism training services

work.name: BBC News
work.summary: I worked on the Money, Work & Tech desk at BBC News, where I covered everything finance-related, from breaking news on budget days to longer-term investigations into business insolvency rates. Most of my stories involved collaborating with reporters across the newsroom, but I also worked on solo projects, some of which were heavily featured on the website, as well as TV and radio programmes. I have also built and maintained an R library to easily and reliably produce charts for online and broadcast, while also working on interactive data visualisation.
highlights: Developed energy price calculator reaching millions of users
Created interactive tools for cost of living coverage

work.name: New Statesman
work.summary: While at the New Statesman, my team’s remit expanded to include around 20 B2B and luxury titles in the New Statesman’s portfolio. Shortly after, I was promoted to Data Projects Editor, leading a small team of dataviz developers and overseeing the production of award-winning data-led visual projects. To improve coverage on the B2B websites, I created ‘autograph’, a semi-automated workflow that accessed a proprietary corporate database, wrote draft articles covering topics such as job trends, M&A deals and trends in corporate filings, created charts for them, and uploaded them to the CMS for review. For a few months, I filled in as head of the 15+ data journalism team at the New Statesman and GlobalData.
highlights: Created Ukraine territory interactive map during the war
Developed personal inflation calculator for UK readers
Analyzed Tory MPs' second job earnings worth over £1m

work.name: New Statesman
work.summary: I wrote stories about British politics, urbanism, renewable energy, foreign direct investment, media, technology and many other topics for the New Statesman and its sister publications. I worked with other reporters (data and non-data) and developers to create high-impact stories that were picked up by other media organisations. My last big project became the second most-read article on the website in the 12 months up to July 2021.
highlights: Created Ukraine territory interactive map during the war
Developed personal inflation calculator for UK readers
Analyzed Tory MPs' second job earnings worth over £1m

work.name: Zoopla
work.summary: Created data-led content for the internal and external communication of one of the UK’s biggest property brands.

work.name: infogr8
work.summary: Developed a marketing strategy for one of London’s top eye clinics, delegated tasks to members of the marketing team.

work.name: My-iClinic
work.summary: Developed a marketing strategy for one of London’s top eye clinics, delegated tasks to members of the marketing team.

work.name: Raadhuus Kafeen
work.summary: Helped launch in-house new media startup KOMETA and produced video news content for social media channels. Managed campaigns for the European Union, SEED Grant, Wine of Moldova, Sandra and other clients.

work.name: Granat
work.summary: Helped launch in-house new media startup KOMETA and produced video news content for social media channels. Managed campaigns for the European Union, SEED Grant, Wine of Moldova, Sandra and other clients.

work.name: Moldova.org
work.summary: Reported on current events & socio-political issues, interviewed regional thought leaders and helped grow the newsroom.
highlights: Revealed secret holding company of Transport Minister

work.name: Liberal Reformists Party
work.summary: Worked on communication strategies for the party.

work.name: Six Flags
work.summary: Worked as a lifeguard at Six Flags America.

work.name: Privesc.Eu
work.summary: Co-founded one of the most successful media startups in Moldova. Broadcasted thousands of hours of video, interviewed top political and entertainment figures and facilitated partnerships.

work.name: Publika TV
work.summary: Wrote copy for De Pe Net.

volunteer.summary: Pitched, wrote and edited data stories related to student and university life for a student-run publication; collaborated with other editors and reporters.
highlights: Created data-driven stories about university experience and student issues
Worked with editorial team to develop data visualizations

volunteer.summary: Co-founded and administered independent media platform focused on promoting freedom of speech and human rights in Moldova.
highlights: Helped establish one of Moldova's first independent online media outlets
Coordinated volunteer contributors and managed digital content

volunteer.summary: Helped develop and launch citizen journalism platform PublicTV.md and Alerte.md, a platform for crowdmapping infrastructure issues in Chisinau.
highlights: Contributed to early civic tech initiatives in Moldova
Trained citizens on using digital tools for reporting local issues

volunteer.summary: Maintained and updated the high school's website while studying there, providing technical support for digital initiatives.
highlights: Managed school's online presence while still a student
Supported teachers with technical expertise for digital projects

awards.title: Most Creative Use of Data Journalism
awards.summary: Recognised for innovative approaches to data visualization and storytelling in journalism.

talks.title: How LLMs can classify thousands of records in minutes
talks.summary: You find yourself staring at a dataset with tens or hundreds of thousands of rows. Maybe you want to get up-to-date FOIA contact details for all government departments in your country, or to find out which political donors have links to the fossil fuels industry. What do you do?

talks.title: Finding a needle in a haystack: How AI can help you identify fossil fuel lobbyists
talks.summary: Without looking it up, would you know if the "Clean Resource Innovation Network" is an oil and gas lobbying organisation? Lobbyists often hide under unintuitive or misleading affiliations that obscure their origins. The work of uncovering their identities can be time-consuming and challenging.

publications.name: Oil wells and wildfires: New California data reveals widespread oil production in fire hazard zones
publications.summary: Oil and gas wells pose risks to health and environment as climate crisis expands California's fire hazard zones.

publications.name: Augmenta: A new tool for AI classification and research
publications.summary: We are making the tool behind some of our investigations available for public use.

publications.name: Fossil fuel donors contributed $19 million to Donald Trump's inaugural fund
publications.summary: Chevron, Exxon and ConocoPhilips among those who donated millions to organise Trump's inauguration ceremonies.

publications.name: How we used AI to help us find lobbyists at COP
publications.summary: Every year, Global Witness works with partners in the Keep Big Polluters Out coalition to identify fossil fuel lobbyists who are attending the COP climate talks. For COP29, we pioneered an AI-assisted approach to the process that streamlined and strengthened our analysis.

publications.name: COP oil companies' emissions are set to cause 17 million heat deaths
publications.summary: Oil firms present at COP summits made $2.6 trillion profits since the Paris Agreement – enough to pay half the cost of climate damage in poor countries.

publications.name: Fossil fuel lobbyists eclipse delegations from most climate-vulnerable nations at COP29 climate talks
publications.summary: At least 1,773 fossil fuel lobbyists have been granted access to the COP29 summit in Baku, underscoring an outsized polluter presence year after year at crucial climate talks, according to a new analysis from the Kick Big Polluters Out (KBPO) coalition.

publications.name: The UK government met with oil lobbyists every day last year
publications.summary: A Global Witness investigation reveals that government officials met with oil and gas lobbyists an average of 1.4 times per working day in 2023.

publications.name: Why winter is a poor argument against bike lanes
publications.summary: Studies confirm that it is substandard infrastructure and maintenance, rather than the cold or the snow, that keeps cyclists off their wheels in winter. One city that's embraced this lesson is Oulu, Finland.

publications.name: Secret holding company of a minister
publications.summary: We reveal that Minister of Transport Iurie Chirinciuc controls Cavio, an Italian furniture holding company, via a close family associate.

publications.name: US new-biz spotlight: Creative activity more than doubles but media slows
publications.summary: The US creative market finished 2023 on a strong note, with new-business billings reaching $3.44bn in November-December, according to Campaign Advertising Intelligence. This is an increase of 130% compared with the same period in 2022, when creative account wins totalled $1.49bn. A big chunk of that growth came from the fast-moving consumer goods sector, for which billings increased from $125.5m in November-December 2022 to $1.41bn in 2023.

publications.name: Canada new-biz spotlight: WPP’s Church & Dwight win is biggest media move
publications.summary: To continue enjoying this article, please sign in. You can register for free for limited further access, or subscribe now for full access to all our content. If you were registered for The Message and are logging into Campaign for the first time, please reset your password.

publications.name: Asia-Pacific new-biz spotlight: BMW, Perfetti and Chery Jaguar Land Rover among biggest media moves
publications.summary: Sign in to continue Email address Password Stay signed in Limited free articles a month Free email bulletins To receive full access to Campaign's content including: Unrestricted access to all The Information and The Knowledge content Access to Campaign's in-depth features and coveted reports including additional School Reports analysis, the Annual Salary Survey, and supplementary insight from Camapign's Best Places to Work Regular data-led insight reports from Campaign AI, our business...

publications.name: Christmas dinner: How much will it cost this year?
publications.summary: Those tucking into a traditional turkey for Christmas dinner shouldn't have to fork out much more than last year. The price of a supermarket frozen bird has gone up by just 1.2% in a year, while fellow festive favourite the mince pie has risen by 25%. Meanwhile, higher-end potatoes, stuffing mix and Brussels sprouts are cheaper, research for the BBC suggests. Overall, a typical Christmas dinner costs around £32.35 this year, which is a 4.3% increase on £31 last year.

publications.name: Energy prices: How much will you pay from January?
publications.summary: The typical annual energy bill for a household in England, Wales and Scotland has increased to £1,928 per year for the first three months of 2024, a rise of £94 from November-December 2023. The figure is based on how much energy the typical household uses. However, how much you'll actually end up paying depends on how much you use, where you live, and how you pay.

publications.name: How does your pay compare with other jobs?
publications.summary: The average full-time worker in the UK was earning nearly £35,000 a year in April, official data shows, a rise of 5.8% on the previous year. The size of that rise varies from job to job, with travel agents getting a pay bump of 21%, while sport coaches saw their earnings fall the most. Despite the increases in pay, most workers' wages rose by less than inflation, the rate at which the cost of goods and services rise.

publications.name: Travel agents lead pay rise league despite cost of living squeeze
publications.summary: Travel agents recorded the biggest rise in pay last year, up 21% in a year, official data shows, with public relations directors and publicans next on the list. Sports coaches saw the largest fall and, overall, UK workers saw earnings fail to keep pace with rising prices. The average full-time worker's wage was nearly £35,000 in April 2023, an increase of 5.8% on the previous year. But the cost of living grew faster than wages over the same period. That ate into workers' spending power.

publications.name: Package holidays in Greece, Spain and Turkey soar in price
publications.summary: Nicu Calcea, Colletta Smith & Lucy HookerBBC NewsAll-inclusive package holidays have jumped in price for Mediterranean hotspots including Majorca and Crete. The average price of a week with full food and board in Majorca in Spain is up 21%. Prices for Tenerife have risen more than 22%, figures from TravelSupermarket showed. Crete in Greece is 25% more expensive than last year.

publications.name: Steaks and coffee protected as shoplifting soars
publications.summary: Steaks are being fitted with security tags and coffee replaced with dummy jars, as supermarkets battle to curb a rise in shoplifting. Some stores are also limiting the number of items on shelves in an attempt to reduce theft. It comes as data analysed by the BBC showed shoplifting offences reached their highest point in four years in March, as the cost of living rises.

publications.name: Cost of homemade cheese sandwich rises by more than a third
publications.summary: The cost of a homemade cheese sandwich has jumped by over a third in one year, according to research for the BBC. The price of two slices of white bread, a serving of butter and mature cheddar has risen to 40p, up 37% over a year. Prices of sandwich fillings including chicken, eggs and ham at supermarkets have soared, while the cost of bread has also risen, the figures suggest.

publications.name: Coming soon
publications.summary: Data journalism has existed since at least the 1800s. But in Eastern Europe, journalism is still slow to innovate, with only a handful of outlets doing any data reporting. This newsletter is an attempt to explore what data journalism could be in that part of the world. My name is Nicu Calcea, and I’m a data journalist based in London, UK. I’m currently at BBC News, and before that, I did data at the New Statesman and a couple of other organisations.

publications.name: Covid-19 is changing FDI - but is it going to last?
publications.summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has diminished the flow of foreign direct investment (FDI) around the world. Now, the virus is set to alter the way in which FDI is thought about in general. In early April, Chinese state-owned venture fund China Reform Holdings attempted to take over Imagination Technologies, a British software and semiconductors technology company.

publications.name: Cross-border dealmaking dwindles as Covid-19 hits
publications.summary: Canadian convenience store giant Couche-Tard, better known as the operator of the Circle K chain, was set to buy petrol station operator Caltex Australia in a $5.6bn deal, saying Caltex was "a strong strategic fit for Couche-Tard and an important component of its Asia Pacific expansion strategy". That was until coronavirus happened.

publications.name: What is the gender pay gap where you work?
publications.summary: With eight out of ten firms still paying their male employees more than women, little progress has been made in closing the gender pay gap in the UK. Some sectors have shown some improvement since 2017/18 when companies were first required to publish figures. The latest figures show that organisations in the public sector reduced their pay gap from 14.5% in favour of men in 2017 to 8.9% in 2022.

publications.name: Men still out-earn women in most jobs
publications.summary: Men still earn more than women, according to data gathered by the BBC. Despite a continued push for equality, the difference in wage has remained at 9.4%, the same level as in 2017/18, when figures were first published. The BBC looked at a company's median pay gap - the difference in pay between the middle-ranking woman and the middle-ranking man.

publications.name: Rent prices: How much have they gone up in your area?
publications.summary: Business reporter, BBC NewsRents for new lets have increased by 11.1% in January 2023 compared to the same month a year before. This figure varies greatly across the UK, with London rents increasing by 15.2%, while those in Northern Ireland increased by 5.7%. Use the tool below to see what the average prices are in your area and how they've increased in the past four years. Your device may not support this visualisation.

publications.name: Byron Burger chain owner shuts sites and axes jobs
publications.summary: The owner of the Byron Burger chain has said it will close nine restaurants and cut 218 jobs in another restructure of the business. Famously Proper Ltd, which also controls the Mother Clucker fried chicken brand, blamed rising costs and lower consumer spending for the move. It is the third time since 2018 that the company has been significantly downsized.

publications.name: Cost of living: If no one comes, we close early, says pub
publications.summary: At the Barn Pub near Rugby, the drinks are ready to be served, but unless lots of customers arrive, staff leave early. "If no regulars come in, we close early," the chef says. "It costs to keep this building heated."The Barn Pub is not alone. A survey from the British Beer and Pub Association, seen by the BBC, suggested most pubs are thinking of cutting down trading hours over the winter.

publications.name: Mexico bucks Tequila/mezcal prices trend - exclusive data
publications.summary: The price of a bottle of Tequila/mezcal has broadly risen more slowly than the inflation, except in two markets – one of which is Mexico, exclusive data for Just Drinks suggests. An analysis of more than 1,100 products sold across more than 30 countries shows Mexico and South Africa are the two countries where the price of a bottle of Tequila/mezcal went up faster than inflation between January 2019 and June/July 2022.

publications.name: Mental Health Survey Results
publications.summary: Interactive article no longer available.

publications.name: Local traffic: How Google Maps harms your neighbourhood
publications.summary: In 2005, Rebecca was looking for a place to live. She chose a nice street in Bromley, London, just next to the quiet Crystal Palace Park and relatively low on traffic. “It was the wide, avenue-like appearance of the road, with its villas and Victorian houses, that I loved about the road,” she tells City Monitor. These days, however, the road looks less appealing. “I cycled here until around 2013 after which I stopped as the traffic levels exploded,” she says.

publications.name: Whisk(e)y price rises yet to keep pace with inflation – exclusive data
publications.summary: As distillers have faced rising costs across a range of inputs, the prices paid by global consumers for whisk(e)y have risen – but, largely, not at the same pace as general inflation, exclusive data for Just Drinks suggests. Analysis by research and intelligence group GlobalData of nearly 7,000 products sold in 40 countries show that, in almost all markets, whisk(e)y prices have increased since January 2019.

publications.name: Where are energy industries clustered in the UK?
publications.summary: Historically, businesses have gravitated towards locations with resources and infrastructure. It is not surprising therefore that many industrial clusters are found in Scotland. Scotland, which received global attention as the host of the COP26 climate conference last year, has gone through a transformation of its energy sector since the discovery of oil and gas 50 years ago.

publications.name: Where are industries clustered in the UK?
publications.summary: In 1980, Financial Times journalist Peta Levi coined the term ‘the Cambridge phenomenon’, which she used to describe the spur of technology and biotechnology companies popping up in the city of Cambridge and its surroundings.

publications.name: Big tech watches you as you read the news
publications.summary: Our investigation into website tracking software has found that news websites have, on average, 17 third party reader tracking tools – and Google trackers are on nearly all of them. “Big Tech companies insist spying on users, government is inadvertent,” reads an August 2020 headline on The Washington Times website, a conservative daily covering the DC area as well as US national politics.

publications.name: Citizenship for sale: How investment buys passports
publications.summary: The rise of residence by investmentWhile most countries reserve the right to grant citizenships to anyone in return for contributions to society, culture and the economy, that right is rarely exercised and there are no set conditions an individual needs to meet to be granted citizenship. Many countries provide residence permits in exchange for investments. The OECD identified 100 countries that offer some form of residence by investment for would-be investors.

publications.name: Heat pumps are on the rise in Europe
publications.summary: Few people in Norway had even heard of heat pumps at the beginning of the millennium. By 2019, some 1.4 million units had been sold in the country, figures from the European Heat Pump Association (EHPA) show. Norway’s rapid adoption of heat pumps was spurred by a series of cold winters, an increase in electricity prices, grants and bans on old boilers. While heat pumps are yet to become widespread around the world, they offer a series of advantages compared with traditional heating solutions.

publications.name: Uber and Lyft are cutting even further into the taxi market during the pandemic
publications.summary: We know what happens when city drivers can't find a street-parking space near their destination: they circle the block until their luck changes. Plenty of research has documented the great toll this takes on traffic congestion and air pollution. The field’s leading scholar, UCLA parking guru Donald Shoup, has found that cruising for parking can account for some 15% of downtown traffic at the lower end of the spectrum, and up to 74% at the extremes.

publications.name: Coronavirus is challenger banks' biggest challenge yet
publications.summary: Online-only banks have seen a significant decrease in new app reviews since around March 2020, when Covid-19 cases began to rise. Credit: Shutterstock Some digital-only banks were struggling even before the lockdown started.

publications.name: Bank branches are closing, and they’re leaving the most disadvantaged areas behind
publications.summary: Covid is changing the ways we get around cities. Governments are advising against the use of mass transit except for essential travel, and those who need to go out are increasingly opting to use more personal forms of transportation, such as bicycles, scooters and their own two feet.

publications.name: Billions in revenue lost and jobs cut as planes remain grounded
publications.summary: A stunning fact emerged from the UK government this week: over the entire month of April 2020, only 112,300 passengers arrived in the country by air – a 99% decline from the same month in 2019. More than half of those passengers were UK nationals returning home. It is hard to overstate the impact of Covid-19 on the aviation industry in countries like the UK. At one point – on April 14 – just 1,900 passengers landed in the country.

publications.name: Airbnb’s coronavirus crisis may be good news for renters in expensive cities
publications.summary: Like many of us, Airbnb is not having a good year. Earlier this May, the company laid off nearly 2,000 employees, or approximately 25% of its workforce.

publications.name: Chart: Global economy to shrink by 1.9% in 2020, with Western Europe down by up to 10%
publications.summary: The global economy is now expected to shrink by 1.9% in 2020, according to experts from GlobalData. Western Europe and the US are still expected to bear the brunt, with Italy’s GDP forecast to contract by 10% over the year. France’s GDP is predicted to shrink by 8.6%, the UK’s by 8.2%, Spain’s by 7.9% and Germany’s by 6.6%. Those forecasts are slightly worse than GlobalData was forecasting a week ago.

publications.name: Nearly 40,000 coronavirus deaths in England and Wales, ONS says
publications.summary: In its 2,500-year history, Naples has witnessed numerous wars, revolutions, natural disasters and invasions. Over the past couple of months, however, Neapolitans experienced something almost entirely new: silence. Italy was the first European country to institute a strict nationwide lockdown to mitigate the spread of the coronavirus.

publications.name: Unemployment claims rise by 69%, highest rate on record
publications.summary: The number of people claiming unemployment benefits has increased to 2.1 million in April 2020 – up 856,500 in a month, and the highest level since 1996. The figures, released this morning by the Department of Work & Pensions (DWP), shows that the number of people claiming Jobseeker's Allowance or searching for work under Universal Credit rules has increased by 69.1% in just one month.

publications.name: Covid-19 cities and regions: North West England close to overtaking London as national "epicentre"
publications.summary: The number of new daily Covid-19 cases had continued to drop in the most affected regions in Europe and America, with most new cases recorded in Mexico and some South American countries. Illinois has overtaken Massachusetts as the third most affected region in the US, with the number of daily new cases there quickly approaching those in New York.

publications.name: Coronavirus involved in more than a quarter of care home residents’ deaths
publications.summary: A political earthquake hit the British capital last night. Transport for London (TfL), a public agency, found itself just hours away from running out of money, and was forced to beg national government for a £2bn bail out. The government agreed – but on much harsher terms than TfL wanted, offering £1.1bn in cash and £505m in loans.

publications.name: Number of patients waiting 6+ weeks for a diagnostic test triples
publications.summary: The number of people waiting six or more weeks for a diagnostic test in England almost tripled in March 2020 alone as Covid-19 saw hospital postpone “non-urgent” treatment. New figures from NHS England show that, by the end of March, 85,446 patients had been waiting six or more weeks for diagnostic tests and procedures – up from 29,832 in February and 26,483 in March 2019.

publications.name: US now double the deaths of UK, Spain and France combined
publications.summary: The number of Covid-19 cases continues to fall with the number of deaths seeing an expected post-weekend slight uptick on Monday, our coronavirus tracker shows. The total number of cases is now at 4,117,502, with the number of confirmed Covid-19 deaths now at 286,330. The US continues to have the biggest share of those, recording 1,156 deaths yesterday.

publications.name: Economic forecast: Western GDP decline estimates revised downward
publications.summary: The GDP growth forecast for European countries and the US have been revised downwards yet again, with estimates for France seeing the biggest drop. Italy remains the country likely to take the biggest hit, according to this week’s GlobalData forecasts, with the country’s economy expected to shrink by 9.4% during 2020.

publications.name: England and Wales have passed deaths peak, ONS figures show
publications.summary: Great news, commuters: the UK government has released its guidance for how to use public transport safely in the age of covid-19. As is often the way with official government documents, the guidance is much shorter than it looks: it frequently repeats itself, as it offers basically the same set of suggestions for when using each different mode of transport. Much of the advice for how to behave in a taxi, it turns out, can also apply on a train.

publications.name: Restrictions are being lifted as cases fall in major cities
publications.summary: One of the most contentious things about Britain’s current lockdown status – or at least, one of the ones which has caused the most spluttering on Twitter, which is not quite the same thing – concerns the question of commuting. Consider this extract from Boris Johnson’s address to the nation last night: “We now need to stress that anyone who can’t work from home, for instance those in construction or manufacturing, should be actively encouraged to go to work.

publications.name: Crime in Northern Ireland falls by one-third during lockdown
publications.summary: The number of crimes recorded in Northern Ireland has fallen by nearly a third in the five weeks starting 23 March – giving us a first glimpse of how the Covid-19 lockdown has affected crime in the UK. The figures, released today by the Police Service of Northern Ireland, shows that all major types of crime have seen a downward progression since the beginning of the lockdown.

publications.name: Chart: Western economies expected to shrink 6 to 9 percent
publications.summary: The economic forecasts for the biggest Western nations affected by Covid-19 have been revised downward once again – with the UK seeing a particularly steep drop-off. Italy’s GDP is expected to drop by more than 9.3% in 2020, according to the latest forecasts from GlobalData. France’s GDP is set to drop by 7.3% during the year, the UK’s by 7.0% and Germany’s by 6.3%.

publications.name: Nearly 40,000 more dead than normal since start of Covid-19 outbreak, ONS says
publications.summary: England and Wales have recorded 38,554 more deaths than usual between the start of the Covid-19 outbreak in March and 24 April, new figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) show. Of those, only 71% were officially attributed to Covid-19 – leaving some 11,260 deaths unaccounted for.

publications.name: Berlin starts to move again amid signs of “lockdown fatigue” elsewhere
publications.summary: Despite coronavirus being commonly referenced as “the great equalizer”, new data has today confirmed it has disproportionately affected poorer neighbourhoods. The most deprived areas of England registered 55.1 deaths linked to Covid-19 per 100,000 people up to April 17, the figures show. The least deprived had a rate less than half of that, at 25.3 deaths per 100,000.

publications.name: Covid-19 disproportionately affects the most deprived, new analysis shows
publications.summary: Despite coronavirus being commonly referenced as “the great equalizer”, new data has today confirmed it has disproportionately affected poorer neighbourhoods. The most deprived areas of England registered 55.1 deaths linked to Covid-19 per 100,000 people up to April 17, the figures show. The least deprived had a rate less than half of that, at 25.3 deaths per 100,000.

publications.name: England and Wales see 27,000 excess deaths since start of Covid-19 pandemic
publications.summary: England and Wales have seen 27,000 more deaths than expected since the start of the Covid-19 outbreak. New figures from the UK's Office for National Statistics show there were more than twice as many deaths in the week ending 17 April than would have been expected in an average year. A total of 22,351 people died during the week – more than twice the 10,497 seen across the previous five years.

publications.name: Where coronavirus stopped pedestrians in their tracks
publications.summary: As the UK locked down amid the coronavirus outbreak, theories abounded about why some parts of the country changed their routines more quickly and to a greater extent than others. Anonymised mobile phone data from Google shows that the amount people moved around for work dropped by more than 60% in Brighton, Bath, York and Edinburgh by 11 April. Those figures were notably lower, however, for Peterborough (47%) and Middlesbrough (50.1%).

publications.name: Coronavirus impacting housing demand after strong start to 2020 - Zoopla
publications.summary: The coronavirus pandemic has led to a 40% drop in interest from buyers. By Nicu Calcea March 26, 2020 Zoopla After a strong start to 2020 in the housing market, we've seen a sharp fall in interest from buyers since the coronavirus pandemic started spreading across the UK. Demand from buyers over the seven days to 22 March was down 40% on the previous week, according to our latest Zoopla Cities House Price Index Report.

publications.name: Revealed: the top 20 features renters want most from a home - Zoopla
publications.summary: Our latest analysis reveals the most popular keywords renters use to find their next home. By Nicu Calcea March 1, 2020 Zoopla What makes a perfect rental home? For some people, it’s having a cosy fireplace to warm up next to and for others, it’s having a nice view of the sea. We looked at the most common terms people used in our keyword search tool between August 2019 and February 2020 to identify the most sought-after features renters are searching for.

publications.name: Long-distance family: First-time-buyers are moving away from their parents - Zoopla
publications.summary: Buying the nest...we reveal how nearly half of all first-time buyers choose to move more than 20 miles away from their parents. By Nicu Calcea March 5, 2020 Zoopla Despite 60% of first-time buyers claiming living close to family is important, the reality is very different. Over three quarters (77%) of first-time buyers don't buy in the same area as their parents, our latest survey reveals.

publications.name: First-time buyers: their needs and challenges - Zoopla
publications.summary: What do buyers look for in their first home? Our survey of more than 2,000 respondents reveals the answers. By Nicu Calcea February 21, 2020 Zoopla When it comes to choosing a home, it’s often what’s on the outside that counts. Almost one in three respondents (29%) to our Zoopla survey of first-time buyers and existing homeowners chose a parking space as their most desirable feature for their first home.

publications.name: The best places to live in Britain if you're single - Zoopla
publications.summary: Whether you’re looking for love or loving single life, these are the best places to live in if you’re single. By Nicu Calcea February 14, 2020 Zoopla Maybe you're happily single or maybe you're ready to mingle. In any case, we know that living alone can be exciting and freeing - but can also feel lonely at times. So whether you’re ready to fall in love or still enjoying the single life, we’re here to help.

publications.name: What do people do first after moving into a new home? - Zoopla
publications.summary: We asked over 2,000 people, both existing homeowners and first-time buyers, to find out. By Nicu Calcea February 10, 2020 Zoopla Moving into your first property can be a long, complex and emotional process. For some, it can take a while to finally settle into their new home.

publications.name: The Highwire Act
publications.summary: Published by Nicu Calcea on October, 2015 Original source: Wizz Air Inflight MagazineTucked behind a main road in Chișinău, standing alone among a forest of of weed-covered paving slabs, is one of Easter Europe’s strangest buildings. The white buttress of the exterior rise from the ground like crooked teeth, while the domed roof resembles a medieval crown.

publications.name: Grade inflation means too many Firsts being awarded, finds OfS report
publications.summary: News · 3 mins ago · Students today are receiving higher marks than ever before according to a report published last month by the Office for Students. The study found that the percentage of students receiving first-class honours has increased from 16% in the 2010-11 academic year to 27% in 2016-17. Better Marks for EveryoneMore than half of the universities in England are awarding marks far higher than their 2010 averages.

publications.name: Londoners more likely to go to university than rest of UK
publications.summary: News · 3 mins ago · Recent reports show that young people from London are more likely to go to university than those from the rest of the UK. Around 42.4 per cent of London-based 18-year-olds were admitted in higher education last year, an increase of 0.7 per cent from 2017. According to the “2018 End of Cycle Report” published by UCAS, Londoners had a 32 per cent higher chance to be admitted to university than their peers in the rest of England.

publications.name: Is University Still Worth Enroling In?
publications.summary: News · 4 mins ago · Hundreds of thousands of students enrol in universities across the UK each year. Teenagers in England and Scotland were more likely to go to university in 2018 than ever before, figures published by UCAS show. Many of them believe that a university degree will help them land better jobs. More than half of students say they went to university because they wanted to pursue a particular career, according to a 2017 survey.

publications.name: Student suicide statistics published for 2016/17
publications.summary: News · 3 months ago · Data on suicide rates among students has been revealed for the first time. The figures, published by the Office for National Statistics, estimates that 95 students took their lives during the 2016/2017 academic year. The number is more or less consistent with previous years. Nearly two thirds of completed suicides were by young men. Most of the students who took their lives were studying at an undergraduate level.

publications.name: London universities drop in employability rankings
publications.summary: London universities drop in employability rankings News · 2 hours ago · British universities continue to struggle with preparing students for the complexities of the modern job market, a new report shows. Out of the 150 best ranking universities in terms of employability in the world this year, only 10 are from the UK with just five from London. The 2011 report included 15 universities from the UK.

publications.name: Think you know what the gender gap in UK is? How many questions will you get right?
publications.summary: Quiz: How well do you know the UK gender pay gap? In October 2017, the gender pay gap in the UK was around 9.1% in favor of men. However, data submitted to the Office for National Statistics by companies with 250+ employers shows that these differences in wages vary widely across professions. For example, female financial institution managers and directors earn 26.2% less, on average, than men.
